hostname_rule.message: Hostname contains 'security' — likely a sensitive/authentication asset; treat as high priority.
Hostname indicates a development environment — these often run less-hardened builds and may expose unnecessary services.
Test or QA environment suggested by hostname — verify that non-production systems are not externally exposed.
Staging environment detected — staging tends to mirror production and may reveal sensitive behavior if reachable.
Production-labelled hostname — presence is expected but usually indicates high-value targets requiring strong hardening.
Hostname suggests internal resources — internal-labelled hosts appearing in public records may signal boundary exposure.
DMZ-labelled hostname — indicates edge systems that should be tightly monitored and isolated.
API-labelled hostname — APIs usually expand the surface area and require consistent versioning and input validation.
Authentication-related naming — indicates sensitive components where weak config or exposure may have high impact.
Database-related naming — should generally not appear as an externally identifiable hostname.
Cache-layer naming — caching layers sometimes expose metadata or internal behavior if not properly gated.
Legacy or deprecated naming — may imply outdated systems that need additional review.
Hostname suggests backup or mirrored systems — these occasionally contain sensitive snapshots or outdated config.
Static or asset distribution hostname — typically low-risk but may reveal deployment structure.
Mail-related hostname — mail servers often expose metadata and require strict transport and auth configuration.
VPN-labelled hostname — external discovery of VPN endpoints may highlight access gateways.
Hostname hints at administration functionality — these should be access-restricted and monitored.
Gateway or edge-host naming — often part of boundary infrastructure that benefits from configuration review.
Cluster-related naming detected — Kubernetes-related hosts should not directly expose control surfaces.
Worker or node naming — suggests internal compute units or autoscaling groups.
Operations or monitoring-related naming — exposure may reveal infrastructure telemetry or configuration.

defaults.message: No hostname pattern matched — general review recommended.
